ans_CoT:

Frogs are cold-blooded animals, which means their body temperature is regulated by the environment. In winter, when temperatures drop significantly, they cannot generate enough heat to maintain their body warmth. So, when a frog burrows into soft mud and freezes, it does so to conserve energy and prevent its body from freezing to death. It will remain frozen until the warmer temperatures of spring arrive, at which point it can thaw and resume its normal activities. However, if the freezing is too severe or lasts too long, the frog may not survive.
